title: 1  Help and Support
text: 1.1 Support Tickets

title: 1  Help and Support
text:
1.2 Office Hours
The OU REDCap teams hosts online office hours on Tuesday (10:30-11:30am) and Thursday (10:30-11:30am) most weeks. But this is subject to change, so check with Thomas if it is important. Please contact Thomas for the Zoom link.
All are welcome to join, from experienced project admins wanting to tweak an existing feature, to newly-hired data entry personnel wanting to be more comfortable with an unfamiliar assignment. Experienced vets are willing to help with most questions.
No PHI is shared during office hours, because people from different projects won’t necessarily be permitted to see your participant data. If possible, create a test record to your project for the sake of the meeting. This will allow attendees to see and learn from your question.

title: 1  Help and Support
text:

The REDCap interface itself offers links to documentation…






Figure 1.1: Embedded Resource.

title: 1  Help and Support
text:
1.4 Training Resources

1.4.1 Training (Training Portal)


1.4.2 Self Guided Tours (Academy)






Callout -tip



Knowledge of biomedical, translational, and clinical data standards is essential for appropriate use of the coded RWD when curating concept sets to apply to the data. Ultimately, that in combination with data availability and data limitations will determine project feasibility.

title: 3  Vocabulary
text:
3.1 General
These general terms for beginners reading Chapters 1 through 8.

title: 3  Vocabulary
text:
3.1.1 Project
A REDCap project is a self-contained …


3.1.2 Server
A REDCap server hosts a collection of projects. Identifying the correct server is the first step to navigating to your desired project.
At OU, the two production servers are https://bbmc.ouhsc.edu and https://redcap.ouhsc.edu.
The first is the newer and larger instance, while the second one (sometimes called the “CoPH server”) is being phased out and no longer accepting new projects.
Beginning users will rarely encounter OU’s “development” server, which is https://redcap-dev-2.ouhsc.edu.


3.1.3 Record
… distinguish w/ event and participant …


3.1.4 Participant
A participant is sometimes synonymous with record, but not always…


3.1.5 Instrument/Form
The terms instrument and form are used interchangeably in REDCap…


3.1.6 Event
A REDCap event is a nested inside a record, typically to facilitate longitudinal data collection within the same participant.


3.1.7 User
Many types of REDCap users can be interact with a single project. See Section 9.2.1 for a list of common roles, ranging from a participant responding to a public survey to a project administrator.

title: 9  User Admin

9.2 User role

9.2.1 Research Team

principle investigator (PI):
project coordinator:
analyst:
nurse:
data entry:
budget:
project admin:
audit:



9.2.2 Participants

public:
private:



9.2.3 OCRI

REDCap Administrator:
graduate research assistant (GRA):



9.2.4 Campus IT
This group of people is vital to the operation of a REDCap instance, but distinguishing their roles probably isn’t helpful to most readers of this manual. The group is composed of experts in security, databases, operating systems, web servers, networking, storage, and virtual machines.

title: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
text: 10.1 Before sending your instruments or survey for testing, the designer (you) will need to:
crumbs: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
text:
10.1.1 Check the field type for every variable
Make sure the field type is what you had meant to select. For instance, is the date field using the correct validation, such as MM/DD/YYYY? Does a multiple-choice item allow only one response? If so, then it needs to be a radio button. A checkbox field allows multiple responses to be chosen on a multiple-choice item.


10.1.2 Use clear language

Many surveys/instruments are completed or used by people of different literacy levels or for whom English is a second language, so it is crucial to be as clear as possible.
Make sure labels are clear and the logic between items is easy to follow. Vague labels and difficult-to-follow logic can lead to items being skipped and data to be missing, or incorrect responses may be entered. Example:







Figure 10.1: Ambiguous “Name”.



Whose name? The person filling out the form? Their first name? Last name? The last name of a family in the home? What if they have different last names? The survey might be clear to the person creating the project, but a second or third set of eyes may catch items that are unclear.


10.1.3 Inspect each field and think about what the data will look like for the person eventually analyzing the data
Example:
With a fill-in-the-blank text field like the one above, here are some of the ways that someone may report a birthday:
January 8, 1999    08 January 1999    Jan 8, 99   1-8-1999
Jan. 8, 1999      jan 8 1999          1999-1-8    8 Jan ‘99
A subsequent analysis would report there were 8 different dates entered, instead of 8 people with the same birthdate. And forget about being able to calculate someone’s current age based on these data! Use data validation in REDCap whenever possible. Go through your items and figure out if you can validate each field in some way. Even something like “Child’s age” could be entered numerous ways in a free-text field:
Seven    7 years old        Don't know      8 on his next birthday
7        7 years, 4 months  I don't know
You might modify your item to specify “Child’s age (in years)” and use data validation to require the person to enter an integer.


10.1.4 Check whether your project is failing to collect necessary data, either by fields not being completed or fields being left off the form

Go back to the original plan for the project and check your work.
What was the purpose of the project? Did every needed field get included in your instruments/survey?
Will the fields in your instruments/survey collect the information required to to fulfill the needs that motivated the project?



10.1.5 Test the survey yourself

Many times, omissions or errors can be found by testing the survey/instrument yourself.
Enter test data. If you are testing a survey, follow along with the paper survey and see if it matches with what is in REDCap.
Review the data you just entered and see if the data is what you expected.
crumbs: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
section: 10.2 When you decide you are ready to have individuals enter test data on your instrument or survey, select the individual(s) that you want to test your project
text:
10.2 When you decide you are ready to have individuals enter test data on your instrument or survey, select the individual(s) that you want to test your project

10.2.1 Have Ask at least one other person to enter test data in your instruments or survey.

Sometimes the person creating the project is too close to it and can’t see its limitations. A second, third or fourth set of eyes is crucial, and they can enter many test records with different scenarios in mind.
Could any of the items be misunderstood by a naïve user?
Check the data entered to see if the questions meet goals of the project? Example:

If people with diabetes need to answer extra questions, has the branching logic been set up correctly so that those items only appear when someone says they have diabetes? Your tester(s) should enter data for different kinds of study participants. This step is important to complete before a project is moved into production because you may not be able to test changes in branching logic at a later point.

Does the survey work equally well on a cell phone vs. a computer? Having multiple testers will allow you to have them test the project on different platforms.
Is there enough room in the text box for answers or do you need to change it to a notes box?

Testing a public survey

Public surveys can be distributed from REDCap email or through an OU email with an embedded link. The tester’s email address is required.
If there is a paper survey, send selected individuals a copy and have them check to see if it matches what they see in REDCap. Other testers can test the survey without using the paper survey.

Testing data collection forms that are not surveys

Testing data collection forms in REDCap (i.e., it is not a public survey), will need to be done by individuals within your group or by individuals that who have access in the project for testing only and will need to be removed from the project prior to pushing the project to production and prior to collecting data collection.



10.2.2 Have at least one other person who is familiar with the study or investigation check whether the REDCap project matches any printed documents, like IRB protocols and approved procedures.

Is the project accurate and staying within the bounds of what has been intended or IRB-approved?
Is the wording correct on all instruments?
Is everything spelled correctly?
Is the skip logic correct? Does the skip logic match what is in the printed survey?
Are all the items present?
Have any items been added that were not approved by the IRB (and therefore should be deleted)?
Are calculated variables producing correct answers?



10.2.3 Ask the individuals testing your instruments/survey if the forms/surveys are user-friendly in its appearance

Are the colors easy on the eyes?
Are colors acceptable for people who are color-blind?
If a team will be entering data directly into REDCap (i.e., it is not a public survey), are the instruments too long? Could the instrument be broken up into shorter instruments so the data entry person doesn’t feel like they’re working on the Great Wall of China?
Could some items be put into a table using the rich text editor in a descriptive field? These tables can save space and require less scrolling by the data entry person. Ask your REDCap Administrator how to do that.
crumbs: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
section: 10.3 When the testers have completed their testing
text:
10.3 When the testers have completed their testing

10.3.1 Make any necessary changes to the survey or data instrument.


10.3.2 Review suggested changes and make changes based on their feedback.


10.3.3 Look at the data that the testers entered into REDCap

Does any of the information look like it would be unusable or not as expected?
Can the field be modified with data validation settings?
Make corrections to the field if necessary.



10.3.4 Are there any text boxes that need to be turned into notes fields?
crumbs: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
section: 10.4 When you are satisfied that everything is perfect
text:
10.4 When you are satisfied that everything is perfect

10.4.1 Move your project to production status by (1) clicking on “Project Setup” tab:


10.4.2 Then scroll down, and (2) click on the button “Move project to production.”


10.4.3 If you have real data entered and don’t want to lose it, click on “Keep ALL data saved so far.”


10.4.4 If everything is test data,
remember to click on “Delete ALL data in the project (including any survey responses), calendar events, documents uploaded onto forms/surveys, and all archived data export files stored in the File Repository, and any logged events that pertain to data collection.”


10.4.5 Click on the button “Yes, Request Admin to Move to Production Status.”
crumbs: 10  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
text:
11.1 Before Testing
Before sending your instruments or survey for testing, the designer (you) will need to:
crumbs: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
text:
11.1.1 Field Type
Check the field type for every variable
Make sure the field type is what you had meant to select. For instance, is the date field using the correct validation, such as MM/DD/YYYY? Does a multiple-choice item allow only one response? If so, then it needs to be a radio button. A checkbox field allows multiple responses to be chosen on a multiple-choice item.


11.1.2 Use clear language

Many surveys/instruments are completed or used by people of different literacy levels or for whom English is a second language, so it is crucial to be as clear as possible.
Make sure labels are clear and the logic between items is easy to follow. Vague labels and difficult-to-follow logic can lead to items being skipped and data to be missing, or incorrect responses may be entered. Example:







Figure 11.1: Ambiguous “Name”.



Whose name? The person filling out the form? Their first name? Last name? The last name of a family in the home? What if they have different last names? The survey might be clear to the person creating the project, but a second or third set of eyes may catch items that are unclear.


11.1.3 Anticipate Analysis
Inspect each field and think about what the data will look like for the person eventually analyzing the data
Example:
With a fill-in-the-blank text field like the one above, here are some of the ways that someone may report a birthday:
January 8, 1999    08 January 1999    Jan 8, 99   1-8-1999
Jan. 8, 1999      jan 8 1999          1999-1-8    8 Jan ‘99
A subsequent analysis would report there were 8 different dates entered, instead of 8 people with the same birth date. And forget about being able to calculate someone’s current age based on these data! Use data validation in REDCap whenever possible. Go through your items and figure out if you can validate each field in some way. Even something like “Child’s age” could be entered numerous ways in a free-text field:
Seven    7 years old        Don't know      8 on his next birthday
7        7 years, 4 months  I don't know
You might modify your item to specify “Child’s age (in years)” and use data validation to require the person to enter an integer.


11.1.4 Necessary Data
Check whether your project is failing to collect necessary data, either by fields not being completed or fields being left off the form

Go back to the original plan for the project and check your work.
What was the purpose of the project? Did every needed field get included in your instruments/survey?
Will the fields in your instruments/survey collect the information required to to fulfill the needs that motivated the project?



11.1.5 Test the survey yourself
Test the survey yourself

Many times, omissions or errors can be found by testing the survey/instrument yourself.
Enter test data. If you are testing a survey, follow along with the paper survey and see if it matches with what is in REDCap.
Review the data you just entered and see if the data is what you expected.
crumbs: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
text:
11.2 Select Testers
When you decide you are ready to have individuals enter test data on your instrument or survey, select the individual(s) that you want to test your project

11.2.1 First Tester
Have Ask at least one other person to enter test data in your instruments or survey

Sometimes the person creating the project is too close to it and can’t see its limitations. A second, third or fourth set of eyes is crucial, and they can enter many test records with different scenarios in mind.
Could any of the items be misunderstood by a naïve user?
Check the data entered to see if the questions meet goals of the project? Example:

If people with diabetes need to answer extra questions, has the branching logic been set up correctly so that those items only appear when someone says they have diabetes? Your tester(s) should enter data for different kinds of study participants. This step is important to complete before a project is moved into production because you may not be able to test changes in branching logic at a later point.

Does the survey work equally well on a cell phone vs. a computer? Having multiple testers will allow you to have them test the project on different platforms.
Is there enough room in the text box for answers or do you need to change it to a notes box?

Testing a public survey

Public surveys can be distributed from REDCap email or through an OU email with an embedded link. The tester’s email address is required.
If there is a paper survey, send selected individuals a copy and have them check to see if it matches what they see in REDCap. Other testers can test the survey without using the paper survey.

Testing data collection forms that are not surveys

Testing data collection forms in REDCap (i.e., it is not a public survey), will need to be done by individuals within your group or by individuals that who have access in the project for testing only and will need to be removed from the project prior to pushing the project to production and prior to collecting data collection.



11.2.2 Compared to Printed Versions
Have at least one other person who is familiar with the study or investigation check whether the REDCap project matches any printed documents, like IRB protocols and approved procedures

Is the project accurate and staying within the bounds of what has been intended or IRB-approved?
Is the wording correct on all instruments?
Is everything spelled correctly?
Is the skip logic correct? Does the skip logic match what is in the printed survey?
Are all the items present?
Have any items been added that were not approved by the IRB (and therefore should be deleted)?
Are calculated variables producing correct answers?



11.2.3 User-Friendly Appearance
Ask the individuals testing your instruments/survey if the forms/surveys are user-friendly in its appearance

Are the colors easy on the eyes?
Are colors acceptable for people who are color-blind?
If a team will be entering data directly into REDCap (i.e., it is not a public survey), are the instruments too long? Could the instrument be broken up into shorter instruments so the data entry person doesn’t feel like they’re working on the Great Wall of China?
Could some items be put into a table using the rich text editor in a descriptive field? These tables can save space and require less scrolling by the data entry person. Ask your REDCap Administrator how to do that.
crumbs: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
text:
11.3 After testing
When the testers have completed their testing

11.3.1 Necessary Changes
Make any necessary changes to the survey or data instrument


11.3.2 Respond to Feedback
Review suggested changes and make changes based on their feedback


11.3.3 Inspect Test Data
Look at the data that the testers entered into REDCap

Does any of the information look like it would be unusable or not as expected?
Can the field be modified with data validation settings?
Make corrections to the field if necessary.



11.3.4 Convert to Notes
Are there any text boxes that need to be turned into notes fields?
crumbs: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project
text:
11.4 Once Satisfied
When you are satisfied that everything is perfect

11.4.1 Project Setup
Move your project to production status by (1) clicking on “Project Setup” tab


11.4.2 Move project to production
Then scroll down, and (2) click on the button “Move project to production.”


11.4.3 Keep ALL data saved so far
If you have real data entered and don’t want to lose it, click on “Keep ALL data saved so far.”


11.4.4 If everything is test data,
remember to click on “Delete ALL data in the project (including any survey responses), calendar events, documents uploaded onto forms/surveys, and all archived data export files stored in the File Repository, and any logged events that pertain to data collection.”


11.4.5 Request Admin to Move
Click on the button “Yes, Request Admin to Move to Production Status.”
crumbs: 11  Checklist for Testing a REDCap Project

title: 12  Can’t log in
text: Chapter Leads: Thomas Wilson

title: REDCap Manual for OU
text:
Welcome
Welcome to REDCap Manual for OU: Training Material for REDCap Users. This collection of documents will help you learn how to use REDCap for research and operations.
Just as the REDCap software expands to meet the needs of more people, this book will grow to accommodate help more types of users learn these tools more efficiently. As you read the following chapters and sections, we hope you feel comfortable editing existing material or adding new lessons, in order to improve the quality of all our work.
Sincerely,
The Editorial Committee

title: REDCap Manual for OU
text:
How to Contribute
We welcome suggestions, edits, and larger contributions to this guide. This book is typeset in Markdown, rendered with Quarto, and hosted on GitHub. For errors or requests, please submit an Issue to the book’s issue tracker. To make larger or direct contributions, please make a pull request using the standard GitHub workflow.
If you would like to contribute but are unfamiliar with any of these technologies, please feel free to email <to be created: redcap@ouhsc.edu> with comments and suggestions for changes. If you would like to discuss the content or receive further help, see the Help and Support Chapter.

title: REDCap Manual for OU
text:
How to Cite this Work
Beasley WH, Wilson T (Eds.) (2024). REDCap Manual for OU: Training Material for REDCap users. DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.14003228
Editorial Committee:

William H. Beasley: October 2024 - present
Thomas Wilson: October 2024 - present
